questions.text: A 16-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department because of fever and poor feeding for 2 days. He became very fussy the previous evening and cried for most of the night. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and weighed 2430 g (5 lb 3 oz). The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother does not recall any sick contacts at home. He currently weighs 2776 g (6 lb 2 oz). He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. He becomes more agitated when picked up. There is full range of motion of his neck and extremities. The anterior fontanelle feels soft and flat. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Blood cultures are drawn and fluid resuscitation is initiated. A urinalysis obtained by catheterization shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An MRI scan of the head is used to diagnose various central nervous system conditions including infections. However, since MRI scans require that patients not move for an extended period of time, children are typically sedated during the procedure. It is therefore not the preferred imaging modality in acutely ill pediatric patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Although studies have suggested that bacterial and viral meningitis can be distinguished based on serum procalcitonin levels, there is no conclusive evidence for this hypothesis. Currently, serum procalcitonin is not routinely measured in the diagnosis of meningitis, which is suspected in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The onset of fever, irritability, jaundice, and poor feeding in a neonate are highly suggestive of a severe disease. Reassurance would result in lack or delay of adequate treatment, leading to further complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine culture is performed to diagnose urinary tract infections (UTIs). In neonates, a UTI may also manifest with unspecific symptoms such as fever, irritability, and poor feeding. If urosepsis develops, it can also lead to meningitis. Urine cultures would only be indicated in case of abnormal urinalysis, which has a high sensitivity for UTI. The first priority in this acutely ill child is to assess him for meningitis and to initiate empiric treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with suspected meningitis and signs of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., seizure, papilledema) a CT scan is typically performed prior to a lumbar puncture, as performing a lumbar puncture in a patient with elevated ICP can lead to brain herniation and death. However, this patient does not present with features suggestive of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., coma, papilledema, focal neurologic deficit) that would prompt a CT scan. In addition, a CT scan would not be the imaging method of choice in a neonate.

F) CORRECT:

A lumbar puncture should be performed in all clinically stable neonates with suspected meningitis or signs of sepsis and no signs of increased intracranial pressure. In neonates, meningitis often manifests with nonspecific symptoms and without the classic triad of meningitis. CSF analysis can confirm the diagnosis and guide antibiotic treatment. Until the results of the CSF analysis are available, patients should be treated with empiric antibiotic therapy (e.g., ampicillin plus gentamicin and/or cefotaxime in patients < 1 month).

In patients with signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., seizures), imaging should be obtained before performing a lumbar puncture. In neonates and infants, a cranial ultrasound is usually the preferred method of neuroimaging. In older children, a CT scan should be performed. Although a bulging fontanelle can be a sign of increased intracranial pressure, it is not an indication for imaging on its own.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
CBC: complete blood count
CRP: C-reactive protein
CSF: cerebrospinal fluid
DDx: differential diagnoses
HSV: herpes simplex virus
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
LP: lumbar puncture
PCR: polymerase chain reaction
VZV: varicella zoster virus

G) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the chest is a first-line diagnostic method upon suspicion of lower respiratory tract infections (e.g., pneumonia). However, this patient does not have any clinical features (e.g., signs of respiratory distress) that suggest this diagnosis.
questions.hint: In neonates with fever, poor feeding, jaundice, and irritability or lethargy, meningitis should always be ruled out!

questions.text:
A previously healthy 3-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department 6 hours after the onset of fever and persistent irritability. He had been well until 2 days ago, when he started feeding poorly and sleeping more than usual. He appears lethargic and irritable when roused for examination. His temperature is 39.0°C (102°F). He cries when he is picked up and when his neck is flexed. The remainder of the physical and neurological examinations show no other abnormalities. His serum glucose is 95 mg/mL. His total serum bilirubin is 6.3 mg/dL. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows:


Pressure
255 mm H2O


Erythrocytes
2/mm3



Leukocyte count
710/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
95%


Lymphocytes
5%


Protein
86 mg/dL


Glucose
22 mg/dL


Gram stain results of the cerebrospinal fluid are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antibiotic regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin, which provides coverage for group B streptococcus, Listeria monocytogenes, and Enterococci, is used in the empiric treatment of neonatal meningitis. Ceftriaxone, however, is contraindicated in neonates with hyperbilirubinemia because it displaces bilirubin from the albumin-binding site and is therefore associated with an increased risk of kernicterus.

B) INCORRECT:

A combination of vancomycin and ceftriaxone is used in the empiric treatment of community-acquired bacterial meningitis in patients between the ages of 1 month and 50 years. However, ceftriaxone is contraindicated in neonates with hyperbilirubinemia because it displaces bilirubin from the albumin-binding site and is therefore associated with an increased risk of kernicterus.

C) INCORRECT:

Cefotaxime covers most gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria and is indicated for the empiric treatment of neonatal meningitis. However, gentamicin is effective only against gram-negative bacteria and would not cover the gram-positive pathogens that are not covered by cefotaxime (e.g., Listeria).

D) CORRECT:

In neonates (age < 1 month), empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis consists of ampicillin plus an aminoglycoside (e.g., gentamicin) and/or a third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., cefotaxime). This regimen covers most pathogens responsible for neonatal meningitis.

See “Empiric antibiotic therapy for bacterial meningitis” table.

E) INCORRECT:

A combination of vancomycin, ampicillin, and cefotaxime is used in the empiric treatment of community-acquired bacterial meningitis in patients > 50 years of age. A different antibiotic regimen is used for the empiric treatment of meningitis in neonates.

F) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin provides coverage for group B Streptococcus, Listeria monocytogenes, and enterococci, while vancomycin provides coverage for drug-resistant gram-positive bacteria. However, doxycycline does not play a role in the empiric treatment of meningitis, with the exception of suspected tick bite-associated meningitis.
questions.hint: The presence of fever, lethargy, and irritability in a neonate with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings of neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose concentration, increased opening pressure, and protein concentration is highly suggestive of late-onset bacterial neonatal meningitis. The pathogens that most commonly cause this disease are group B streptococcus, gram-negative bacilli (e.g., Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species), and Listeria monocytogenes.

questions.text: An 8-day-old, 2200 g (4 lb 14 oz) male newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding and irritability. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation after the pregnancy was complicated by premature rupture of membranes. His APGAR scores at delivery were 5 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 170/min, and respirations are 63/min. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and nasal flaring. Capillary refill time is 4 seconds. Laboratory studies, including blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid cultures, are pending, and an x-ray of the chest is scheduled. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phototherapy is indicated as the primary treatment for pathological neonatal jaundice in a neonate. Although this condition could manifest with icterus in a tachycardic, restless, preterm infant, pathological neonatal jaundice typically occurs within 24 hours of birth. Moreover, a diagnosis of pathological neonatal jaundice would not explain the tachypnea and subcostal retractions in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is used to treat symptomatic neonates with congenital hyperthyroidism. This condition can cause irritability, restlessness, and tachycardia in a neonate. However, congenital hyperthyroidism is strongly associated with a history of maternal Graves disease, as it is the transplacental passage of maternal TRAbs that causes this condition. Moreover, this diagnosis would not account for the tachypnea, jaundice, and subcostal retractions in this newborn.

C) INCORRECT:

Alveolar surfactant is administered intratracheally in neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which can manifest with signs of increased breathing effort (e.g., tachypnea, nasal flaring) in a preterm neonate. However, the clinical features of NRDS appear immediately after birth and the affected child would have cyanosis rather than icterus.

D) CORRECT:

Combined therapy with intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin provides broad-spectrum coverage for the most commonly implicated pathogens in neonatal sepsis (group B Streptococcus, Escherichia coli, coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, S. aureus, Klebsiella). This therapy can be initiated based on clinical suspicion in any neonate with features suggestive of neonatal sepsis and later adjusted according to antibiogram results.

Streptococcus agalactiae and E. coli are the most common causes of both early-onset and late-onset neonatal sepsis.

E) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation would be indicated in a child with severe airway compromise. This could occur in neonatal pneumonia, which is the likely cause of sepsis in this child. However, without any features suggestive of airway compromise (cyanosis, poor respiratory effort, wheezing), this intervention is not indicated.
questions.hint: Fever, irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, tachycardia, tachypnea, and jaundice in a late preterm infant 8 days after delivery are suggestive of late-onset neonatal sepsis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 4 hours after spontaneous rupture of membranes. She has had mild abdominal discomfort and nausea for a day. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes, which is controlled with a strict diet. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of placental abruption. Current medications include iron and vitamin supplements. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 122/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows severe, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. Speculum examination confirms rupture of membranes with drainage of malodorous, blood-tinged fluid. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 175/min and reactive with no decelerations. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,100/mm3



Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 K+

3.9 mEq/L


 Glucose
98 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein
Negative


 Glucose
1+


 Blood
Negative


 WBC
3–4/hpf


 RBC
Negative


 Nitrites
Negative


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Influenza typically manifests with the sudden onset of high fever, headache, muscle/joint aches, nonproductive cough, and severe malaise. Inflammatory markers are usually normal. Influenza does not account for PPROM, leukocytosis, or fetal tachycardia seen here.

B) CORRECT:

The combination of maternal fever, tachycardia, uterine tenderness, malodorous and purulent amniotic fluid, vaginal discharge, and fetal tachycardia indicates chorioamnionitis. A major risk factor for chorioamnionitis is PPROM, which is observed in this patient. Chorioamnionitis is a clinical diagnosis. Maternal blood tests frequently reveal leukocytosis. Treatment depends on whether the birth is vaginal (requiring IV ampicillin plus gentamicin) or cesarean (requiring IV ampicillin and gentamicin, plus clindamycin).

C) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with fever, nausea, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants, and leukocytosis, which may mimic the presentation of acute appendicitis. However, appendicitis does not account for a constellation of PPROM, purulent vaginal discharge, and fetal tachycardia seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of PPROM with maternal fever, leukocytosis, drainage of malodorous, blood-tinged fluid, and fetal tachycardia is highly suggestive of an infection. These features are not associated with normal labor.

E) INCORRECT:

Pregnant women have an increased risk of UTI and therefore also pyelonephritis, which could explain this patient's abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. However, urinalysis in pyelonephritis would typically reveal pyuria (positive esterase on dipstick test), leukocyturia, WBC casts, positive nitrites, and microhematuria. Pyelonephritis, moreover, is not associated with PPROM.

F) INCORRECT:

Although uterine rupture causes abdominal pain and fetal tachycardia and is more likely in patients who have had a c-section in the past, the condition generally occurs during labor and results in hemodynamic instability, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, this patient has fever and leukocytosis, which are consistent with another diagnosis.
questions.hint: Common risk factors for this condition include prolonged labor and preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM).

questions.text:
A 3100-g (6.8-lb) male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of fever and irritability. The newborn was delivered at home 15 hours ago. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation. The mother's last prenatal visit was at the beginning of the first trimester. She received all standard immunizations upon emigrating from Mexico 2 years ago. Seven weeks ago, she experienced an episode of painful, itching genital vesicles, which resolved spontaneously within a week. Four hours before going into labor, she noticed a gush of pale yellow fluid from her vagina. The newborn appears ill and lethargic. His temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. His skin is mildly icteric. Expiratory grunting is heard on auscultation. Skin turgor and muscle tone are decreased. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15 g/dL


Leukocyte count
33,800/mm3


Platelet count
100,000/mm3



Serum glucose
55 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of late-onset neonatal sepsis, which occurs between 3 and 28 days of life, not 15 hours after birth. S. aureus commonly manifests with skin, soft tissue, or bone infections in newborns that progress to sepsis. This neonate has no skin lesions to suggest an infection with S. aureus.

B) INCORRECT:

Clostridium botulinum causes botulism, which manifests with hypotonia in newborns, as seen in this patient. However, infantile botulism also presents with ptosis, poor suck, poor head control, and flaccid paralysis, none of which are present in this case. Moreover, infantile botulism does not present with fever and signs of sepsis. Additionally, this infant has no risk factors for botulism (e.g., exposure to dust or honey).
Image Description:

This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

C) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes can occasionally cause neonatal sepsis (especially during outbreaks of listeriosis), but it is not the most common pathogen. Although early-onset meningitis manifests with nonspecific symptoms (e.g., fever, irritability, tachycardia), L. monocytogenes commonly causes meningitis at age 2–4 weeks rather than within hours of birth.

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis causes meningitis and can rapidly progress to sepsis. Although Neisserial meningitis can manifest with nonspecific symptoms like fever, irritability, and tachycardia as seen in this patient, it is exceedingly rare in the first week of life.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes genital herpes and can be transferred to a newborn during childbirth. Neonatal HSV infection manifests with thrombocytopenia and disseminated sepsis-like illness. However, HSV infection also typically manifests with vesicular skin lesions, which this patient does not have. The patient's mother had a painful vesicular genital rash, likely due to genital herpes, but it resolved 6 weeks before the onset of labor, greatly reducing the risk of transmission. Although HSV may be vertically transmitted in the absence of an active maternal genital rash, a different organism is the more likely cause of this newborn's illness.

F) CORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae, i.e., group B Streptococcus (GBS), is the most common pathogen in early-onset neonatal sepsis (< 72 hours after delivery). Common causes of this condition include chorioamnionitis and bacterial colonization of the maternal genital tract with intrapartum pathogen transfer to the infant. A common risk factor is premature rupture of membranes (PROM), as evidenced by the gush of pale yellow fluid prior to the onset of labor in this patient's mother.

Routine screening for maternal GBS colonization is performed by rectal or vaginal swab cultures from 36 0/7 to 37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Treatment with intrapartum penicillin G or ampicillin is indicated in birthing parents with positive screening, GBS bacteriuria, history of GBS infection, or risk factors (e.g., PROM, fever, preterm labor). Treatment of GBS neonatal sepsis includes parenteral ampicillin and gentamicin.
questions.hint: This newborn's ill appearance, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and elevated leukocyte count 15 hours after birth raise concern for early-onset neonatal sepsis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of worsening pelvic pain for 2 hours. Three days ago, she had a burning sensation with urination that resolved spontaneously. She has nausea and has vomited fluid twice on her way to the hospital. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.7°C (103.5°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness. No contractions are felt. Speculum examination shows pooling of nonbloody, malodorous fluid in the vaginal vault. The cervix is not effaced or dilated. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 14 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 250,000/mm3. Fetal heart rate is 148/min and reactive with no decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin and perform cesarean delivery
Administer oral azithromycin and induce labor
Administer intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin and induce labor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy and prompt delivery are critical components of the management of chorioamnionitis. A regimen of intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin is the appropriate antibiotic therapy for patients with this condition. However, cesarean delivery should only be performed in patients with chorioamnionitis who have standard obstetric indications (e.g., failure to progress during labor, nonreassuring fetal status), none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, if cesarean delivery is performed, patients should also receive antibiotic coverage of anaerobic bacteria with either clindamycin or metronidazole.

B) INCORRECT:

Prompt delivery is a critical component of the management of chorioamnionitis. However, expectant management is inappropriate for this patient, who does not have uterine contractions or cervical changes and thus should receive induction of labor. Moreover, prompt delivery alone is insufficient to treat chorioamnionitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Prompt delivery and antibiotic therapy are critical components of the management of chorioamnionitis. Induction of labor is appropriate for this patient, who does not have uterine contractions or cervical changes. However, azithromycin is not routinely used as part of the antibiotic regimen to treat chorioamnionitis.

D) CORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy and prompt delivery are critical components of the management of chorioamnionitis. A regimen of intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin is the appropriate antibiotic therapy for patients with this condition. This patient, who does not have uterine contractions or cervical changes, should receive induction of labor. Augmentation of labor is appropriate for patients with prolonged labor or inadequate uterine contractions.

E) INCORRECT:

Cesarean delivery should only be performed in patients with chorioamnionitis who have standard obstetric indications (e.g., failure to progress during labor, nonreassuring fetal status), none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, prompt delivery alone is insufficient to treat chorioamnionitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Prompt delivery is a critical component of the management of chorioamnionitis. This patient, who does not have uterine contractions or cervical changes, should receive induction of labor. However, prompt delivery alone is insufficient to treat chorioamnionitis.
questions.hint: This patient, who is at 36 weeks' gestation, recently had a urinary tract infection and now has diffuse abdominal tenderness, nausea, vomiting, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and leukocytosis. These features, together with malodorous amniotic fluid, indicate a diagnosis of chorioamnionitis with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). There are no signs of severe fetal distress (e.g., fetal tachycardia).

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her current pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anemia treated with iron tablets. She has received routine prenatal care, but she has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by an infection with GBS that resulted in sepsis in the newborn. The patient has no history of serious illness. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt every 4 minutes. There is clear amniotic fluid pooling in the vagina. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture and intravenous penicillin administration
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing and intravenous penicillin administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Culture of GBS is usually indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Indications for prophylaxis include maternal GBS colonization, GBS bacteriuria occurring during pregnancy, or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient). Because this patient already has an indication for prophylaxis, GBS screening cultures are not required.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient is most likely colonized by GBS and should receive a different intervention to avoid intrapartum transmission and a subsequent negative outcome in her unborn child.

C) INCORRECT:

Culture of GBS is indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. However, patients with GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient) require prophylaxis. Therefore, she does not require further testing, as it would not influence the treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Routine screening for GBS colonization of all pregnant women via culture of vaginal and rectal swabs is indicated between 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Women with GBS bacteriuria occurring anytime during pregnancy or history of a previous newborn with GBS infection, as in this patient, should receive routine prophylactic antibiotics and do not have to undergo prior screening for GBS colonization.

Other maternal risk factors for GBS infection that serve as indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with unknown antepartum culture status include fever, preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, or positive intrapartum nucleic acid amplification testing for GBS.

E) INCORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) can be used for rapid intrapartum diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization in women with an unknown culture status. However, NAAT is not routinely used because of its low sensitivity compared to standard GBS culture. Moreover, the management of cases with a possible maternal GBS colonization and an unknown antepartum culture status should be based on maternal risk factors rather than NAAT results. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Colonization or active infections (e.g., chorioamnionitis) do not routinely justify a cesarean delivery. However, if an infection presents along with fetal distress or there is any other standard obstetric indication (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions), the patient would require a cesarean delivery.
questions.hint: This patient's first child had sepsis due to a GBS infection. It is essential to prevent the infection from recurring in her second child.

questions.text: A 2980-g (6.6-lb) female newborn is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of worsening lethargy. The newborn was delivered at home 10 hours ago. The mother has had no prenatal care. The newborn's temperature is 39.7°C (103.5°F). Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Her leukocyte count is 36,000/mm3 (85% segmented neutrophils). An organism is isolated from the blood. When grown together on sheep agar, the isolated organism enlarges the area of clear hemolysis formed by Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clostridium botulinum is gram-positive, obligate anaerobic rods that cause botulism, which manifests with hypotonia, flaccid paralysis, and poor suck in newborns. Infantile botulism does not manifest with fever and signs of sepsis, and this infant has no risk factors for botulism (e.g., exposure to spores contained in honey). While C. botulinum is a β-hemolytic pathogen, this patient's blood culture findings suggest a pathogen that produces CAMP factor, which is not typical for Clostridium botulinum.
Image Description:

This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is not a common cause of early-onset neonatal sepsis, and this patient lacks risk factors for neonatal P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., birth weight < 1500 g, intensive care unit stay). While P. aeruginosa is a β-hemolytic pathogen, this patient's blood culture findings suggest a pathogen that produces CAMP factor, rather than P. aeruginosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes are gram-positive, intracellular rods that occasionally cause neonatal sepsis (especially during outbreaks of listeriosis). Although L. monocytogenes is a weakly β-hemolytic pathogen that is CAMP factor positive, another pathogen is much more likely to have caused this patient's symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a β-hemolytic and catalase-negative bacteria. S. pyogenes may form the clear area of hemolysis on blood agar, as seen in this patient, but will not enlarge the area of hemolysis formed by Staphylococcus aureus, as it lacks the CAMP factor produced by the causal organism.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptocccus pneumoniae is not a common cause of neonatal sepsis. These α-hemolytic and catalase-negative bacteria cause a greenish discoloration on blood agar due to partial reduction of hemoglobin, unlike the clear area of hemolysis formed by the causal organism in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae (i.e., group B streptococcus (GBS)) is a β-hemolytic, gram-positive cocci that colonizes the vaginal mucosa and is among the most common causative pathogens of early-onset neonatal sepsis. Routine pregnancy screening at 36+0 to 37+6 weeks of gestation with rectal and vaginal swabs is recommended. Transmission of GBS to neonates can be prevented via administration of intrapartum penicillin prophylaxis. This patient's lack of prenatal care increased her child's risk of GBS sepsis.

Common causes for early-onset neonatal sepsis include chorioamnionitis and bacterial colonization of the maternal genital tract with intrapartum pathogen transfer to the infant.
Image Description:

Bacterial culture (grown on Columbia horse blood agar)

Left: α-hemolysis
Partial hemolysis produces a greenish intermediate product. α-hemolytic Streptococcus species are called viridans streptococci (from Latin “viridis,” green), the most common being S. pneumoniae.

Middle: β-hemolysis
Complete hemolysis manifests as translucent agar. β-hemolytic Streptococcus species can be classified according to Lancefield groups (clinically relevant: A and B), S. pyogenes (group A) being the best known.

Right: γ-hemolysis
The term γ-hemolysis is a misnomer, as, in fact, no hemolysis takes place. The best known γ-hemolytic species are those of the Enterococcus genus.
questions.hint: This newborn's fever, lethargy, and elevated leukocyte count are concerning for neonatal sepsis, which is often accompanied by jaundice and dehydration. The causal organism produces CAMP factor, a protein that enhances the effect of β-lysin of S. aureus, thereby enlarging the area of clear hemolysis.

questions.text: A 6-day-old female infant is brought to the emergency department because of poor feeding and irritability for two days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation, and the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F). She appears lethargic and makes occasional twitching movements in both upper extremities. The anterior fontanelle is soft and full. A lumbar puncture is performed and analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid shows increased protein and decreased glucose. Cerebrospinal fluid culture shows gram-positive, intracellular rods with tumbling motility. Infection of a healthy adult with the pathogen affecting this infant would most likely present with which of the following clinical conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is the most common pathogen implicated in cystitis. E. coli can cause neonatal meningitis, as seen in this patient. However, E. coli is a gram-negative rather than a gram-positive rod, and, therefore, is not the pathogen responsible for this patient's condition. Listeria monocytogenes is not typically known to cause cystitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most commonly implicated pathogen for pneumonia in healthy adults. Although it is a common pathogen responsible for meningitis in infants (1 month to 2 years), it is uncommon in neonates. Listeria monocytogenes is not a common cause of pneumonia in healthy adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are the most common bacteria responsible for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) in adolescents and adults. Although these bacteria can cause neonatal infections, these typically manifest with conjunctivitis and not with the meningitis seen in this patient. Listeria monocytogenes is not known to cause PID.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis are the most commonly implicated bacterial pathogens in meningitis in healthy adults. Although these are also the most common pathogens responsible for meningitis in infants (1 month to 2 years), they are uncommon in neonates. Listeria monocytogenes, the pathogen responsible for this patient's presentation, can cause meningitis in adults; however, it typically only affects older adults (> 60 years) or immunocompromised individuals. Another condition is more likely in a healthy adult with L. monocytogenes.

E) CORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes most commonly causes self-limited gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It classically is accompanied by a history of dairy product or deli meat consumption (it grows well at refrigeration temperatures). Although typically a self-limiting condition in healthy adults, Listeria infection is more concerning in infants, older adults, and those with compromised immune systems. These high-risk individuals should be treated with ampicillin.
questions.hint: This baby has signs and symptoms of meningitis. Gram-positive intracellular rods with tumbling motility is suggestive of infection with Listeria monocytogenes.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation comes for a prenatal visit. She reports some tiredness but has otherwise been well. She was successfully treated with fosfomycin for asymptomatic group B Streptococcus bacteriuria in the first trimester. She has since moved to a different state and has not attended any further routine prenatal visits. Last year, while she was being treated with amoxicillin for bacterial sinusitis, she developed a rash on her chest that resolved spontaneously. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus that is consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Collection of rectovaginal swab for culture
Administration of penicillin to the newborn after delivery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's history of asymptomatic GBS bacteriuria in the first trimester warrants intrapartum GBS prophylaxis regardless of GBS culture results. Cefazolin is the antibiotic of choice for neonatal GBS prophylaxis in women who have a history of mild penicillin allergy. Patients with a high risk for anaphylaxis (e.g., a history of immediate flushing, angioedema, respiratory distress after penicillin intake) require intrapartum clindamycin, or vancomycin if GBS is resistant to clindamycin. If allergy status is unclear, penicillin skin testing should be performed prior to labor.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrapartum penicillin is indicated for intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with GBS colonization who do not have a history of anaphylactic reaction to penicillin. This patient has a history of a mild reaction to amoxicillin and therefore requires a different approach.

C) INCORRECT:

A rectovaginal swab for GBS culture is generally indicated between 36+0–37+6 weeks' gestation to determine GBS status and whether intrapartum prophylactic antibiotics are necessary to prevent neonatal GBS infection. However, in patients who have developed GBS bacteriuria at any point during the current pregnancy and in patients with a history of previous delivery of a newborn with GBS infection, intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated without prior GBS culture.

D) INCORRECT:

Administration of penicillin after delivery is indicated for all neonates with confirmed GBS infection. Vaginally delivered neonates of women with GBS colonization have a higher risk of developing early onset GBS infection. However, preventive administration of antibiotics to the neonate is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

A urine culture is indicated in all pregnant patients, typically at 12–16 weeks' gestation, to screen for asymptomatic bacteriuria, which is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes (e.g., preterm labor, low birth weight). Repeat urine culture is also required around one week after treatment to ensure that the therapy has been effective. However, a urine culture in this patient has already confirmed asymptomatic GBS bacteriuria, which was successfully treated. A different intervention is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: Indications for intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis include positive screening culture for group B Streptococcus (GBS), previous delivery of a newborn with GBS infection, and GBS bacteriuria at any time during pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old primigravida woman at 39 weeks’ gestation has been in labor for 12 hours after spontaneous rupture of membranes with clear fluid. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she is negative for group B streptococcus. Epidural anesthesia is provided.
The nurse has noted the appearance of intermittent variable decelerations every 5 to 10 minutes. The baseline fetal heart rate is 165 beats per minute. The woman’s contractions are occurring every 4 to 5 minutes.
She has a temperature of 38.3°C, a blood pressure of 116/74 mm Hg, a heart rate of 106 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Cervical examination reveals that she is 9 cm dilated, 100% effaced, and at –1 station.
In addition to treating with acetaminophen, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Place an intrauterine pressure catheter, infuse a 500-cc saline amnioinfusion, and observe the patient
Administer an intravenous fluid bolus, and reposition the patient
Administer ampicillin and gentamicin, and continue the labor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An amnioinfusion to treat variable decelerations would not affect chorioamnionitis because the infection typically involves fetal membranes and the placenta.

B) INCORRECT:

A bolus of intravenous fluid and patient repositioning may mitigate the fetal heart tracing abnormalities and maternal tachycardia but would not treat the underlying infection.

C) INCORRECT:

The time between diagnosis of chorioamnionitis and delivery has not been shown to affect maternal or fetal outcomes, so immediately proceeding to cesarean delivery is not recommended.

D) CORRECT:

Chorioamnionitis is a clinical diagnosis made on the basis of maternal fever >38.0°C and at least two of the following criteria: maternal tachycardia, fetal tachycardia (>160 beats per minute), uterine tenderness, and purulent/foul amniotic fluid. The infection is usually polymicrobial and ascends from the vaginal canal, so broad-spectrum antibiotics are necessary to treat it. Given the paucity of clinical trials, it is best to follow consensus recommendations for treatment with ampicillin and gentamicin. Intrapartum antibiotic treatment has been shown to reduce the risk for neonatal sepsis.

The time between diagnosis of chorioamnionitis and delivery has not been shown to affect maternal or fetal outcomes, so immediately proceeding to cesarean delivery is not recommended. Laboratory testing can be considered when the diagnosis is unclear or in the setting of preterm prelabor rupture of membranes. A left shift or bandemia can support the diagnosis, but an elevated leukocyte count is common with labor and is not itself indicative of infection. The value of any laboratory test to guide management has not been determined.

Key learning point: For a pregnant woman with chorioamnionitis, the most appropriate antibiotic regimen is a combination of ampicillin and gentamicin.

E) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin may be indicated to augment labor if the patient does not have a cervical change within the next 2 hours, but this woman’s labor is progressing appropriately for now.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 39 weeks and 4 days’ gestation presents to labor and delivery with suspected spontaneous rupture of membranes. She reports a 2-hour history of leakage of fluid from the vagina and the onset of mild-to-moderate contractions approximately every 10 minutes. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and her only significant medical history is a childhood allergy to penicillin that resulted in a hospitalization.
During initial examination, there was pooling of nitrazine-positive vaginal fluid that ferned on microscopy testing. During the subsequent 6 hours after admission, the cervix progressed from 4 cm to 8 cm dilated, from 50% to 100% effaced, and from the –2 to the 0 station.
Fetal heart-rate monitoring initially revealed a category I strip with a baseline heart rate of 165 beats per minute and moderate variability. Variable decelerations are now 120 beats per minute lasting 20 seconds with rapid return to baseline. The patient's temperature is taken, and she is found to have a fever to 38.2°C.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient at this time?

choices.text: Initiate intravenous vancomycin, and proceed to cesarean delivery
Administer acetaminophen, and allow labor to continue to progress spontaneously
Initiate intravenous clindamycin and gentamicin, and allow labor to continue to progress spontaneously
Administer acetaminophen, and proceed to cesarean delivery
Initiate intravenous cefoxitin and gentamicin, and allow labor to continue to progress spontaneously

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Evidence-based data to guide the antibiotic choice in patients with penicillin allergy are lacking, and some institutions will use vancomycin with gentamicin. However, vancomycin alone is not adequate. Vaginal delivery is reasonable in the setting of chorioamnionitis, unless there are specific indications for cesarean delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

Untreated chorioamnionitis could lead to maternal and fetal mortality, so treating the patient with acetaminophen and simply proceeding to delivery would be inappropriate. Using acetaminophen in addition to an appropriate antibiotic regimen would be useful, especially if maternal tachycardia exists.

C) CORRECT:

This clinical scenario is consistent with chorioamnionitis, which is defined as maternal fever ≥38.0°C plus at least one of the following symptoms: uterine tenderness, fetal tachycardia (>160 beats per minute), maternal leukocytosis, maternal tachycardia (>100 beats per minute), or foul-smelling amniotic fluid.

Chorioamnionitis is associated with maternal complications, including labor abnormalities, cesarean delivery, uterine atony, and postpartum hemorrhage. Management consists of immediate treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. The most tested antibiotic regimen for chorioamnionitis is a combination of ampicillin (2 grams intravenously every 6 hours) plus gentamicin (1.5 mg/kg intravenously every 8 hours). If the patient requires cesarean delivery, metronidazole or clindamycin should be added to this regimen to enhance coverage of anaerobic organisms.

Patients with chorioamnionitis who are allergic to penicillin should be given clindamycin (900 mg intravenously every 8 hours) plus gentamicin (1.5 mg/kg intravenously every 8 hours). If cesarean delivery is required in this setting, the addition of metronidazole is not necessary because clindamycin has excellent anaerobic coverage. Evidence-based data to guide the antibiotic choice in patients with penicillin allergy are lacking, and some institutions will use vancomycin with gentamicin.

Vaginal delivery is reasonable in the setting of chorioamnionitis, unless there are specific indications for cesarean delivery. In this case, there are no such indications — the fetal heart rate is tachycardic, but the strip is otherwise relatively reassuring, and labor is likely to progress quickly given the mother's multiparous state.

Key learning point: The most appropriate antibiotic regimen to treat chorioamnionitis in a woman with a penicillin allergy is clindamycin and gentamicin.

D) INCORRECT:

Untreated chorioamnionitis could lead to maternal and fetal mortality, so treating the patient with acetaminophen and simply proceeding to delivery would be inappropriate. Using acetaminophen in addition to an appropriate antibiotic regimen would be useful, especially if maternal tachycardia exists. Vaginal delivery is reasonable in the setting of chorioamnionitis, unless there are specific indications for cesarean delivery.

E) INCORRECT:

Cefoxitin (a cephalosporin) has known cross-reactivity with penicillin and is therefore not appropriate in a patient who may have previously had an anaphylactic reaction to penicillin (as indicated by the history of hospitalization for penicillin allergy).

questions.text:
An infant boy is born precipitously by vaginal delivery at 38 weeks and 2 days’ gestation. The mother presented in active labor with a fever of 38.2°C, tachycardia (heart rate 112 beats per minute), and uterine tenderness. She has blood type AB+; negative tests for HIV, hepatitis B virus, syphilis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia; and a positive test for group B streptococcus. She did not receive intrapartum antibiotic therapy. At presentation, the membranes had been ruptured for approximately 16 hours.
Upon delivery, the infant cried at the perineum. Apgar scores were 6 at one minute and 8 at five minutes.
On examination, the infant moves all extremities but has slightly decreased tone and acral cyanosis. He has no rash or pallor but is grunting with tachypnea and nasal flaring. His anterior fontanel is open, soft, and flat. His heart rate is approximately 180 beats per minute with no appreciable murmur. Both lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Neurologic examination is nonfocal with a symmetric Moro reflex.
In addition to obtaining a complete blood count and blood culture, what is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this infant?

choices.text: Initiate empiric antibiotic therapy only if the child becomes febrile
Defer initiation of antibiotic therapy until complete blood count results are available
Initiate therapy with ampicillin and gentamicin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A third-generation cephalosporin is a reasonable alternative to an aminoglycoside. However, given its propensity to displace bilirubin from albumin, ceftriaxone is contraindicated in neonates.

B) INCORRECT:

Neonatal sepsis can cause significant morbidity and mortality. Clinical signs and symptoms can be nonspecific, and it is inappropriate to delay initiation of antibiotic therapy to cover likely organisms in a high-risk infant with signs of neonatal sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Neonatal sepsis can cause significant morbidity and mortality. Clinical signs and symptoms can be nonspecific, and it is inappropriate to delay initiation of antibiotic therapy to cover likely organisms in a high-risk infant with signs of neonatal sepsis.

D) INCORRECT:

Use of vancomycin as monotherapy in early-onset neonatal sepsis does not provide adequate coverage against E. coli and other gram-negative organisms.

E) CORRECT:

Chorioamnionitis is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal sepsis. In the presence of a maternal fever >38°C, a clinical diagnosis of chorioamnionitis can be made if any two of the following features are present:

• Maternal tachycardia >100 beats per minute
• Fetal tachycardia >160 beats per minute
• Maternal leukocytosis (>15,000 leukocytes per mm3)
• Uterine tenderness
• Foul-smelling amniotic fluid

Infants born to mothers with chorioamnionitis who are also colonized with group B streptococcus and do not receive intrapartum antibiotics are at high risk for early-onset sepsis and warrant early evaluation, including blood culture and complete blood count with differential. In addition, current American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines recommend that ampicillin and gentamicin be initiated for empiric coverage against the most common pathogens in early-onset neonatal sepsis: group B streptococcus (GBS), Escherichia coli, and Listeria monocytogenes. Of note, many hospitals are moving away from giving antibiotics empirically to all infants born to mothers with chorioamnionitis and are instead using sepsis calculators (e.g., Kaiser Permanente’s Neonatal Early-Onset Sepsis Calculator), serial physical examinations, or both to determine which neonates are most likely to benefit from empiric antibiotics. Because this infant is ill-appearing with hypotonia and respiratory distress, both of which are potential early signs of sepsis, administration of antibiotics to cover likely pathogens is recommended.

Key learning point: The most appropriate empiric antibiotic regimen for an ill-appearing infant who is born to a mother with clinical evidence of chorioamnionitis is ampicillin and gentamicin.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department with fever and poor feeding. He was born at 40 weeks’ gestation to a healthy mother. Membranes were ruptured for 12 hours before vaginal delivery. Both the pregnancy and the delivery were uncomplicated, and he was discharged home at 48 hours. The mother had a negative screening for Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococcus).
On examination, the patient has a rectal temperature of 38.8°C, a heart rate of 160 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 60 breaths per minute. He has poor tone and does not cry during the examination. His lungs are clear, and there is no murmur or abnormal heart sounds. His abdomen is soft. His skin is cool and mottled; his pulses are graded as 2+, and the capillary refill is 3 seconds.
A full evaluation for sepsis is initiated. The serum leukocyte count is 40,000 cells per mm3 (reference range, 9400–34,000) with 17% neutrophils, 63% lymphocytes, 8% mononuclear cells, and 8% bands.
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis yields the following findings:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocytes (cells/μL)
2
<30


Erythrocytes (cells/μL)
3
3–23


Glucose (mg/dL)
56
>50


Protein (mg/dL)
70
65–150


Blood, urine, and CSF are sent for culture. Antibiotics are initiated while the culture results are pending.
Which one of the following empiric antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cefepime, a fourth-generation cephalosporin, provides gram-negative coverage that is too broad for the organisms typically implicated in EOS — and it does not cover L. monocytogenes.

B) CORRECT:

Early-onset sepsis (EOS) — defined as infection in the bloodstream, urine, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), or any other sterile tissue within 72 hours of life — occurs in 1 to 2 per 1000 full-term infants in the United States and has a mortality rate of about 3%. Neonates with serious bacterial or viral infections may present with nonspecific signs: hyperthermia or hypothermia, lethargy, poor feeding, or apnea.

The organisms most commonly isolated in full-term infants with culture-positive EOS are Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococcus [GBS]; 43% of cases) and Escherichia coli (29%). Since the implementation of routine GBS screening and intrapartum chemoprophylaxis in the United States, the incidence of early-onset GBS disease has dropped by 80% to 0.24 per 1000 live births. Besides GBS and E. coli, other organisms implicated in EOS include Listeria monocytogenes and, rarely, Streptococcus pyogenes, Viridans streptococci, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Empiric treatment of EOS while culture results are pending should consist of antimicrobials that cover the most common neonatal infections. The treatment of choice for presumptive early-onset GBS infection or E. coli septicemia is ampicillin and an aminoglycoside (usually gentamicin); this combination covers the most common causes of EOS and provides synergistic activity against both GBS and L. monocytogenes.

Monotherapy with penicillin G is recommended when GBS is identified as the cause of the infection, and clinical and microbiologic responses have been documented; ampicillin is an acceptable alternative in that scenario. However, ampicillin alone is not appropriate for empiric therapy because E. coli has significant resistance to ampicillin. E. coli is generally sensitive to gentamicin, although this agent is not recommended as monotherapy because of poor CSF penetration and the rapid development of resistance.

Key learning point: The most appropriate empiric antibiotic regimen for early-onset sepsis in a neonate is ampicillin and an aminoglycoside (usually gentamicin).

C) INCORRECT:

EOS caused by L. monocytogenes is less common than GBS infection or E. coli septicemia but should always be considered in the setting of neonatal sepsis. Cephalosporins are not active against L. monocytogenes. Furthermore, ceftriaxone is contraindicated in neonates because it is highly protein-bound and may displace bilirubin, leading to a risk for kernicterus.

D) INCORRECT:

Cefotaxime is not recommended routinely for empiric treatment of EOS because resistance develops rapidly among gram-negative organisms when this agent is used consistently to treat neonatal EOS. Cefotaxime has excellent CSF penetration and should be restricted for use in infants with confirmed early-onset meningitis from gram-negative organisms. For empiric therapy of late-onset meningitis (caused by GBS, L. monocytogenes, or gram-negative organisms), ampicillin and either an aminoglycoside or cefotaxime are recommended. Many clinicians would empirically initiate all three agents (ampicillin, cefotaxime, and an aminoglycoside) in the setting of bacterial meningitis in a neonate, pending organism identification. The infant in this case does not have CSF findings that are concerning for meningitis, so the third-generation cephalosporin is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with penicillin G is recommended when GBS is identified as the cause of the infection, and clinical and microbiologic responses have been documented; ampicillin is an acceptable alternative in that scenario. However, ampicillin alone is not appropriate for empiric therapy because E. coli has significant resistance to ampicillin.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. She has received routine prenatal care, but she has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by an infection with GBS that resulted in sepsis in the newborn. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt every 4 minutes. There is clear amniotic fluid pooling in the vagina. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing and intravenous penicillin administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is most likely colonized by GBS and should receive a different intervention to avoid intrapartum transmission and a subsequent negative outcome in her unborn child.

B) INCORRECT:

Culture of GBS is indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. However, patients with GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient) require prophylaxis. Therefore, she does not require further testing, as it would not influence the treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Routine screening for GBS colonization of all pregnant women via culture of vaginal and rectal swabs is indicated between 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Women with GBS bacteriuria occurring anytime during pregnancy or history of a previous newborn with GBS infection, as in this patient, should receive routine prophylactic antibiotics and do not have to undergo prior screening for GBS colonization.

Other maternal risk factors for GBS infection that serve as indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with unknown antepartum culture status include fever, preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, or positive intrapartum nucleic acid amplification testing for GBS.

D) INCORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) can be used for rapid intrapartum diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization in women with an unknown culture status. However, NAAT is not routinely used because of its low sensitivity compared to standard GBS culture. Moreover, the management of cases with a possible maternal GBS colonization and an unknown antepartum culture status should be based on maternal risk factors rather than NAAT results. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonization or active infections (e.g., chorioamnionitis) do not routinely justify a cesarean delivery. However, if an infection presents along with fetal distress or there is any other standard obstetric indication (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions), the patient would require a cesarean delivery.
questions.hint: This patient's first child had sepsis due to a GBS infection. It is essential to prevent the infection from recurring in her second child.

questions.text: You are seeing an 8-day-old male newborn, weighing 2200 g, who is brought to your clinic because of poor feeding and irritability. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation following a pregnancy complicated by premature rupture of membranes. His APGAR scores were 5 at 1 minute and 8 at 5 minutes. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 38.5°C, pulse is 170/min, and respirations are 63/min. On examination, he has scleral icterus, nasal flaring, and a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Laboratory studies, including blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid cultures, are pending, and a chest x-ray is scheduled. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is used to treat symptomatic neonates with congenital hyperthyroidism. This condition can cause irritability, restlessness, and tachycardia in a neonate. However, congenital hyperthyroidism is strongly associated with a history of maternal Graves disease, as it is the transplacental passage of maternal TRAbs that causes this condition. Moreover, this diagnosis would not account for the tachypnea, jaundice, and subcostal retractions in this newborn.

B) INCORRECT:

Phototherapy is indicated as the primary treatment for pathological neonatal jaundice in a neonate. Although this condition could manifest with icterus in a tachycardic, restless, preterm infant, pathological neonatal jaundice typically occurs within 24 hours of birth. Moreover, a diagnosis of pathological neonatal jaundice would not explain the tachypnea and subcostal retractions in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Alveolar surfactant is administered intratracheally in neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which can manifest with signs of increased breathing effort (e.g., tachypnea, nasal flaring) in a preterm neonate. However, the clinical features of NRDS appear immediately after birth and the affected child would have cyanosis rather than icterus.

D) CORRECT:

Combined therapy with intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin provides broad-spectrum coverage for the most commonly implicated pathogens in late-onset neonatal sepsis (Escherichia coli, coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, S. aureus, Klebsiella). This therapy can be initiated based on clinical suspicion in any neonate with features suggestive of neonatal sepsis and later adjusted according to antibiogram results.

E. coli is the most common cause of both early-onset and late-onset neonatal sepsis.

Key learning point: Empiric intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin are the initial antibiotics of choice for suspected late-onset neonatal sepsis to provide broad-spectrum coverage against common pathogens.

E) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation would be indicated in a child with severe airway compromise. This could occur in neonatal pneumonia, which is the likely cause of sepsis in this child. However, without any features suggestive of airway compromise (cyanosis, poor respiratory effort, wheezing), this intervention is not indicated.
questions.hint: Fever, irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, tachycardia, tachypnea, and jaundice in a late preterm infant 8 days after delivery are suggestive of late-onset neonatal sepsis.
